The "Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002" amends the National Dam Safety Program Act by focusing on Federal programs and coordination among agencies for implementing dam safety guidelines. The "Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002" amends the National Dam Safety Program Act by updating duties and objectives related to dam safety in the United States. The amendments include changes to strategic planning, cooperation with governmental entities, and the development of security guidelines for dams. The "Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002" updates the National Dam Safety Program Act by amending duties and objectives related to dam safety in the United States. This includes developing technical assistance materials, seminars, and guidelines to improve dam security, coordinating national efforts to enhance dam safety, and providing assistance for state dam safety programs. The "Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002" amends Section 8 of the National Dam Safety Program Act to provide assistance for state dam safety programs. This includes establishing, maintaining, and improving dam safety programs with allocated funds. The "Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002" amends Section 8 of the National Dam Safety Program Act to improve dam safety programs by revising operating procedures and agreements. The Board is established to monitor dam safety in the United States and advise on national dam safety policy. The "Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002" amends Section 8 of the National Dam Safety Program Act to improve dam safety programs by revising operating procedures and agreements. The Board is established to monitor State implementation, advise the Director on national dam safety policy, and amend voting and nonvoting membership. The Board, in consultation with the Director, may invite representatives from National Laboratories of the Department of Energy, Federal or State agencies, or dam safety experts as nonvoting members. The Board's duties include promoting effective dam safety programs nationwide and facilitating coordination among Federal and State agencies for enhancing dam safety. The Board may establish work groups to assist in achieving its goals, consisting of Board members and other selected individuals. Travel expenses for Board members representing Federal agencies may be reimbursed by their respective agencies. Each member of the Board representing a Federal agency will be reimbursed for travel expenses by their agency, including per diem, while performing services for the Board. Members representing State agencies, the private sector, and work groups will be reimbursed by FEMA for travel expenses. SEC. 4. RESEARCH.

Amends Section 9(a) to include cooperation with the Board, support for developing information resources systems for dam safety, and initiatives for improving dam safety engineering, security, and management.

SEC. 5. DAM SAFETY TRAINING.

Amends the Act to include dam safety training as Section 10. SEC. 5. DAM SAFETY TRAINING.

Amends the Act to provide training for State dam safety staff and inspectors upon request from States with or developing dam safety programs. Section 13 of the Act is amended to increase annual amounts to $6,000,000 for fiscal years 2003 through 2006. Allocation changes include updating references to sections and removing specific assistance needs. Research funding is set at $1,500,000 annually for fiscal years 2003 through 2006. In fiscal years 2003 through 2006, funding is authorized for research, dam safety training, and additional staff personnel under sections 8 through 10 of the Act.
